intro: Oxyacantha monogyna var. acuminata, commonly known as the sharp-fruited dogwood, is a deciduous shrub native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its clusters of white flowers that bloom in late spring, followed by bright red berries in the autumn. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters and has a dense, bushy habit. Its leaves are ovate to elliptic in shape, with serrated edges and a dark green upper surface. The berries are an important food source for birds and are also used in traditional herbal medicine.
